titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Went this evening to the play, and saw the Indians in England, a comedy of Kotzebue; the poorest play of this author, that I have ever seen— Met Mr: Arbuthnot walking— The widow of the late Landgrave of Hesse-Cassel, died very suddenly this day, of an apoplectic fit.
2. Miss Brown’s birth-day— Mrs: A— went with them to Charlottenburg— After their return, they spent the evening at Dr: Brown’s— I was there about an hour.— The weather extremely warm.

3. Found this afternoon a new walk in the park, at the right hand, beyond Bellevue.— Visit this morning from Mr: Parry whom we saw last year at Dresden.— Met Mr: Garlike as I was walking home, in the park.

4. Mrs: A. unwell again with a head ache— The weather continues at high summer heat— Walk in the park in the forenoon and again in the evening. The English prince Augustus, set out last Monday morning for England.
5. Walking in the park before dinner I met the Chevalier d’Aguilar.— Walk’d with him, about half an hour— But a small part of the Evening at home.

6. Call’d this forenoon at Mr: Schickler’s counting house— Visit to Mr: Parry, who was not at his lodgings— Mrs: A— went this afternoon to Charlottenburg, to the wedding of Mrs: Brown’s maid. I was an hour this evening at the Casino.— Finish’d the 11th: book of Oberon.

7. Began upon the 12th: book of Oberon, and busied at it the whole day— Walking before dinner and in the evening— Afterwards with Mrs: A—latter part of the evening at Dr: Brown’s— Mr: Arbuthnot came in while we were there.

8. Dined with a large diplomatic company at the Baron de Krudener’s, who has now just been received as Russian Minister here— Took a ride with Mrs: A—in the afternoon, upon the Potsdam road— Walk in the park again this Evening.

9. The weather continues extremely warm— This afternoon and evening I took a longer walk than usual; went round the pheasant-enclosure, and came out near Charlottenburg.— Repair’d the arrears of yesterday.
10. The weather this morning by a sudden change grew cold, and continued so all day— I went to the Casino before dinner— Long walk again after dinner in the park—

11. Went out and dined, with Mr: & Mrs: Schickler, at Strahlan— The weather very cold— In the afternoon we went down upon the river in a pleasure boat— Did not come home untill nine in the evening. It occasion’d a great interruption of my work—!

12. At a large dinner given by the Minister Alvensleben.— The prince of Orange—the Marquis of Douglas, son to the duke of Hamilton, and thirty other persons were of the company. On coming home called with Mrs: A— at Genl: O’Farrill’s, but his lady was not at home— The two youngest Miss Brown’s pass’d the evening with Mrs: A. Walk’d under the trees. Visit this morning from Mr: Parry, & Mr: Carlyon.

13. Took my lesson from Mr: Catel— Wrote a short letter to Mr: Bourne, and pass’d the rest of the day, at my usual occupation— At the Casino twice— Genl: O’Farrill and his lady call’d on Mrs: A— She spent the Evening at Mrs: Brown’s, and I was there about an hour.

14. Mr: Garlike and Mr: Arbuthnot, Mr: Parry, & Mr: Carlyon, and Miss Brown dined with us. In the afternoon Countess Pauline Neale, who has just returned from Paris call’d to see Mrs: Adams. Madame O’Farrill came to tea— Interrupted again in my studies.

15. Mr: Catel— At the play this evening— Saw the Barbier de Seville with Paësiello’s music. The performance tolerably good— But Unzelmann makes a very indifferent Figaro— Weather again very cold this night.
16. Dined at Baron Krudener’s, with a company of about thirty persons. Mrs: Adams very unwell all day; but in the evening extremely ill—we are apprehensive, with the fever and ague.—

17. Mrs: A— somewhat better though yet far from well.— Was at the Casino before dinner. Dr: Brown and his eldest daughter with us, part of the evening.— Rain’d a little— Walking in the park after dinner.
18. Mrs: A— continues ill with a very severe cough— Read a sermon of Tillotson— Upon the example of Jesus, who went about doing good— Long walks, and very busy ones—

19. Up the whole night with Mrs: A. who cough’d without intermission from 10 at night, untill nearly 4. this morning.— Was obliged in the night to call up Dr: Brown— She obtained at length a temporary relief from a potion with Laudanum. This day she has continued ill— Miss Brown past a couple of hours with her in the Evening— At night she had a very severe fainting fit.

20. Mrs: A— had a little rest, in the night. but not much, and through this whole day has been in a frequent series of faintings— Mrs: Brown called before dinner, and Miss Bell in the Evening.— The disease is the influenza; which she has with more violence than I could have conceiv’d to be possible.

21. My wife had another night nearly as bad as any of the former; yet has been through the day rather better than any of the former days— Miss Brown here in the Evening— The annual reviews began this day. Mr: Arbuthnot called upon me— He found them unpleasant from the excessive dust and sand— The season being remarkably dry.

22. Mrs: A— after a tolerable night, has been this day, upon the whole much better— Finished my translation of Wieland’s Oberon— Mrs: Brown spent a couple of hours here in the Evening— Letter from Mr: Poleske, at London— He brings with him the ratification of the Treaty.

23. Last day of the reviews— Mr: Arbuthnot called upon me; and a Mr: Tidyman, an American, from South-Carolina— A ball at Court— I stay’d there not more than an hour— Miss Brown spent an hour this afternoon with Mrs: A— who seems to be recovering from her illness

24. Weather excessively hot all day— A slight thunder-shower in the Evening; The two eldest Miss Brown’s called upon Mrs: A— who continues to be recovering. I was half an hour before dinner at the Casino. Reading Ruffhead’s life of Pope

25. Mrs: A. is so far recover’d that she was able to take a short ride this forenoon— Mr: Arbuthnot called upon me; and I walk’d with him in the park— Walk’d again alone in the afternoon— Countess Brühl called to see Mrs: A— received letters from my brother Thomas.
26. Mrs: A— continues better— Miss Esdorff called this afternoon to see her, and the three Miss Brown’s. Walk’d before dinner and again towards Evening— Wrote to my mother.

27. Mr: Parry and Mr: Carlyon called upon me this forenoon to take leave; they are going to Stockholm. Was an hour at the Casino before dinner— Walk’d in the park, and again this evening.— Busied upon the 13th: Satyre of Juvenal.

28. Mr: Thompson, an American gentleman with a french tongue called upon me this forenoon for a passport. At the Casino, before dinner— Long walk in the park towards Evening. Mrs: A— went to Strahlan.

29. At length we had some rain after a very long season of dry weather— I could not walk for it, this Evening in the park— Miss Brown was about an hour with Mrs: A.— I contrive to make myself very busy, and to do very little.
30. Dined at the Minister Struensee’s, with a company of nearly thirty persons.— Had some conversation with the Minister Schrötter— Took a long walk in the park after dinner.

31. Mr: Paleske, the Prussian Consul in America, call’d this morning, and brought me dispatches and letters from Philadelphia; with the ratification of the Treaty, concluded last Summer— Reading American newspapers and pamphlets— Mr: Engel call’d on me too this morning.

Day. As that of the last months— But having now finish’d my translation of the Oberon, I spend a couple of hours before breakfast, in making a copy of it, endeavouring as I proceed to give a little polish to the verse; a point in which it is extremely defective— After breakfast I write letters; and in my walking hours amuse myself with a Satyre of Juvenal.
